PUBLIC FINANCE COMMITTEE REPORT .. ( .. ) (The Hon. M.A. Sumanthiran) Sir, I present the Report of the Committee on Public Finance on, (i) Note on the Supplementary Allocations given from the Budgetary Support Services and Contingent Liabilities provision made under the Department of National Budget as per the Introduction Note of the Annual Estimates; (ii) Orders under the Excise (Special Provisions) Act, No. 13 of 1989; and (iii) Resolution under the Active Liability Management Act, No. 8 of 2018 which were referred to the said Committee. . . Ordered to lie upon the Table. ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS ( ) (The Hon. Speaker) 1 - 39/'18 - (1), . ( ) (The Hon. Hesha Withanage) , . ( ) (The Hon. Gayantha Karunatileka) , , . - . . ( ) (The Hon. Speaker) , . : : DESTROYED ALTERNATE ONION CULTIVATION: COMPENSATION 90/18 2. ( ) (The Hon. Dayasiri Jayasekara), , - (1):
() , ? asked the Minister of Agriculture, Livestock Development, Irrigation and Fisheries and Aquatic Resources Development:
(i) the extent of land brought under potato cultivation in Jaffna District in 2017;
(ii) whether the necessary seeds have been provided on time to farmers who cultivated potato in the previous season;
(iii) if not, whether arrangements have been made to provide seeds necessary for red onion cultivation as an alternative; and
(iv) the reasons which prevented the provision of seed potatoes for cultivation on time?
(b) Will he also inform this House-
(i) whether the farmers income has increased as a result of the red onion cultivation provided as an alternative;
(ii) if not, whether the red onion cultivations have been destroyed;
(iii) if so, the reason for that;
(iv) the amounts paid, if compensation has been paid by the Government for the destroyed cultivations; and
(v) if such compensation has not been provided, the reason for that?
(c) If not, why? . ( . ) (The Hon. P. Harrison) , .

Padma Udhayashantha Gunasekera), - (3): () (i) , ; (ii) , ; (iii) , ; (iv) ; ; (v) ;
() , ? asked the Minister of Housing, Construction and Cultural Affairs:
(i) the number of archaeological sites that have been identified in Mahiyanganaya Divisional Secretary's Division in Badulla District, along with their names;
(ii) whether there are any archaeological sites in the aforesaid division, which have been identified but excavations have not been done in them;
(iii) if so, the aforesaid archaeological sites;
(iv) the number of Rajamaha Viharas in the aforesaid division, which have an archaeological value; whether a report of them will be submitted; and
(v) whether a detailed report of the allocations made for the conservation activities of the aforesaid archaeological sites will be submitted?
(b) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Gayantha Karunatileka) , , . () (i) 48. * 01 . (ii) . (iii) * 02 . (iv) 05. * 03 . (v) . .

7 -433/'19- (1), . ( ) (The Hon.Kanaka Herath) , . ( ) (The Hon. Gayantha Karunatileka) , . . . Question ordered to stand down. : : DEVELOPMENT OF TOURISM INDUSTRY: PROGRAMMES IMPLEMENTED 454/19
asked the Minister of Tourism Development, Wildlife and Christian Religious Affairs:

(a) Will he inform this House in relation to the Kandy District - (i) the names of places of tourist attraction; (ii) the names of the institutes that provide accommodation facilities for tourists; (iii) separately, the number of hotels classified based on the star rating of hotels and the names of those hotels; and (iv) separately, the names of tourist restaurants classified based on the tourist restaurant grading system?
(b) Will he also inform this House in relation to year 2017 -
(i) the programmes that were implemented by the Ministry for developing the tourism industry;
(ii) the total amount of money that was spent on those programmes; and
(iii) the names of the programmes that were implemented in order to improve the security of tourists?
(c) Will he state the special plans that have been prepared for attracting more tourists in the coming years?

(d) If not, why? ( , ) ( - , ) (The Hon. John Amaratunga - Minister of Tourism Development, Wild Life and Christian Religious Affairs) , . 5, 6 . , . ( ) (The Hon. Speaker) , ? ( ) (The Hon. Ananda Aluthgamage) , . ( ) (The Hon. John Amaratunga) , . , * . * : * : * Answer tabled:

( ) (The Hon. Thushara Indunil Amarasena) - (1):
asked the Minister of Primary Industries and Social Empowerment:
(i) the income that Sri Lanka earned by betel exports from years 2010 to 2014 and from the year 2017 to date;
(ii) the number of families engaged in betel cultivation in Kurunegala District;
(iii) whether he is aware that the farmers are unable to sell their betel since Pakistan, the major betel purchaser of Sri lanka, has imposed huge taxes; and
(iv) the measures taken by the Ministry having intervened into aforesaid situation in order to uplift the living standards of the betel farmers?
( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Daya Gamage - Minister of Primary Industries and Social Empowerment) , .

LANDS IN GRAMA NILADHARI DIVISION OF PANAMA SOUTH: SUSPENSION OF CULTIVATION 816/19 14. . ( . ) (The Hon. T. Ranjith De Zoysa) , , , - (1):
asked the Prime Minister and Minister of National Policies, Economic Affairs, Resettlement and Rehabilitation, Northern Province Development and Youth Affairs:

(i) whether he is aware that officers of the Forest Conservation Department have ordered suspension of cultivation which had been conducted up to the Maha Season of 2016/2017 since the year 1984 on lands located within the Grama Niladhari Division of Panama South in the Lahugala Divisional Secretary's Division belonging to Ampara District;
(ii) if so, what the reasons for it are;
(iii) which officer gave the order for that purpose;
(iv) whether permission has been given to farmers to resume cultivation on the lands in question; and
(v) if so, on what date such permission was given?
( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Ajith Mannapperuma - State Minister of Mahaweli Development and Environment) , , , , .

( ) , ? asked the Minister of Megapolis and Western Development :
(a) Is he aware that- (i) Padavi Parakramapura Town is situated in a densely populated area; and (ii) the town has not been properly planned?
(b) Since it is suitable to develop this town under the city development project, will he inform this House of the date that required action would be taken in this regard?
(c) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Gayantha Karunatileka) , * . * : * : * Answer tabled: () (i) . (ii) , . ( )

asked the Minister of Primary Industries and Social Empowerment:
(i) the number of Samurdhi recipient families as at 31.10. 2018;
(ii) the number of persons who received Samurdhi benefits as at 31.10.2018; and
(iii) the difference between the number of persons who received Samurdhi benefits as at 31.12.2014 and the number of persons who received Samurdhi benefits as at 31.10. 2018 ?
: : TICKETS ISSUED BY DEVELOPMENT LOTTERIES BOARD: DETAILS
636/18 12. ( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Mahinda Amaraweera on behalf of the Hon. Susantha Punchinilame) - (1):
(a) Will he inform this House what the lottery tickets issued by the Development Lotteries Board are?
(b) Will he also inform this House separately, according to each year-
(ii) the amount or the percentage allocated as prize money from the total revenue earned from sales;
(iii) the number of winners in the ascending order of the prize money won after sales; and
(iv) the amount left with the Government annually from the unsold lottery tickets with prizes or due to unclaimed prize money;
from each lottery issued during the period 2010-2018?
(c) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Gayantha Karunatileka) , * . * : * : * Answer tabled:

GSMB : GSMB : REVENUE RECEIVED BY GOVERNMENT FROM GSMB : DETAILS 757/19 13. () ( ) ( () - ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Bandula Gunawardane on behalf of the Hon. Roshan Ranasinghe) , , , - (2): () (i) 2019.01.01 2019.01.31 GSMB ; (ii) GSMB ( ) ;
() , ? asked the Prime Minister and Minister of National Policies, Economic Affairs, Resettlement and Rehabilitation, Northern Province Development and Youth Affairs :
(i) the volume of sand issued from the Manampitiya boat landing stage via the GSMB Technical Services (Pvt) Ltd. during the period from 01.01.2019 to 31.01.2019; and
(ii) the manner in which priority (issuing of tokens) is given when issuing sand via the GSMB on a daily basis?
(b) Will he also inform this House -
(i) the revenue received by the Government on daily and monthly basis for the Manampitiya boat landing stage from the GSMB;
(ii) separately, the total revenue received by the Government according to each year via the GSMB from year 2013 to 2018; and
(iii) the account to which the revenue is credited to?
(c) If not, why ? ( ) (The Hon. Gayantha Karunatileka) , , , , * .

: 2019 21 : 2019 21 PRIVILEGE : SUMMONING BEFORE SELECT COMMITTEE TO LOOK INTO AND REPORT TO PARLIAMENT ON THE TERRORIST ATTACKS THAT TOOK PLACE IN DIFFERENT PLACES IN SRI LANKA ON 21ST APRIL, 2019 ( ) (The Hon. Dayasiri Jayasekara) , .
Erskine May . Lok Sabha Kaul and Shakdher Practice and Procedure of Parliament" Discussion on sub judice Matters .

It is the absolute privilege of the Legislatures and members thereof to discuss and deliberate upon all matters pertaining to the governance of the country and its people. Freedom of speech on the floor of the House is the essence of parliamentary democracy. Certain restrictions on this freedom have, to a limited degree, been self-imposed. One such restriction is that the discussions on matters pending adjudication before courts of law should be avoided on the floor of the House, so that the courts function uninfluenced by anything said outside the ambit of trial in dealing with such matters. . , , . ( ) (The Hon. Speaker) . , . ( ) (The Hon. Dayasiri Jayasekara) , Erskine May, "Parliamentary Practice" Twenty-fourth Edition "Matters awaiting judicial decision" . , :

Subject to the discretion of the Chair and to the right of the House to legislate on any matter or to discuss any matters of delegated legislation, matters awaiting the adjudication of a court of law should not be brought forward in debate.

II () () WAGES BOARDS (AMENDMENT) BILL

. 2019 23 , , . , . 2019 23, . Presented by the Hon. Gayantha Karunatileka on behalf of the Non-Cabinet Minister of Labour and Trade Unions Relations; to be read a Second time upon Tuesday, 23rd July, 2019 and to be printed; and to be referred to the relevant Sectoral Oversight Committee.

SITTINGS OF THE PARLIAMENT ( ) (The Hon. Lakshman Kiriella) Sir, I move, "That notwithstanding the provisions of Standing Order 8 of the Parliament, the hours of sittings of Parliament on Wednesday 10th and Thursday 11th July, 2019 shall be 10.30 a.m. to 12.30 p.m. and 1.30 p.m. to 6.30 p.m. At 6.30 p.m., Mr. Speaker shall adjourn the Parliament without question put." , . . Question put, and agreed to. MINISTERIAL CONSULTATIVE COMMITTEES ( ) (The Hon. Lakshman Kiriella) Sir, I move, "That notwithstanding the resolution adopted by Parliament on 24th January, 2019, the designations of the following Ministerial Consultative Committees shall be redesignated as follows as per the decision taken by the Committee of Selection on 08th July, 2019. The Ministerial Consultative Committee on Agriculture, Rural Economic Affairs, Livestock Development, Irrigation and Fisheries & Aquatic Resources Development as 'Ministerial Consultative Committee on Agriculture, Livestock Development, Irrigation and Fisheries & Aquatic Resources Development'; and The Ministerial Consultative Committee on Public Administration & Disaster Management as 'Ministerial Consultative Committee on Public Administration, Disaster Management and Rural Economic Affairs'."

SELVAM ADAIKKALANATHAN] took the Chair. : : SUPPLEMENTARY SUM: ROAD DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES ( ) (The Hon. Lakshman Kiriella) Sir, on behalf of the Minister of Highways and Road Development and Petroleum Resources Development, I move, That a supplementary sum not exceeding Rupees Sixty Five Thousand Million (Rupees 65,000 Million) be payable out of the consolidated fund of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka or any other fund or monies of or at the disposal of the Government of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka or from the proceed of any loans obtained by the Government of the Democratic Socialist Republic of Sri Lanka for service of the Financial Year beginning of the 01st of January 2019 and ending on 31st December 2019 and that the said sum may be expended as specified in the schedule hereto:- SCHEDULE Head - 117 Ministry of Highways & Road Development and Petroleum Resources Development Programme - 02 Development Activities Rs. Million Recurrent Expenditure - Capital Expenditure 65,000 Total Expenditure 65,000 Project 03 Expressways Development 57,131 Foreign Loans (Financing Code 12) 55,818 Foreign Finance Related Domestic Co- 1,313 Financing (Financing Code 18) 04 Highways Development 6,044 Foreign Loans (Financing Code 12) 5,564 Foreign Finance Associated Cost 480 (Financing Code 17) 05 Widening & Improvement of Roads 500 Domestic Funds (Financing Code 11) 500 06 Construction of Bridges and Flyovers 225 Foreign Finance Associated Cost 225 (Financing Code 17)
07 Natural Disaster Affected Roads Rehabilitation 1,100 Foreign Loans (Financing Code 12) 1,100 65,000 (Cabinet approval signified.)

. . Question proposed. ( ) (The Hon. Deputy Chairman of Committees) Next, the Hon. Mangala Samaraweera, Minister of Finance. [2.53p.m.] ( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Mangala Samaraweera - Minister of Finance) Mr. Deputy Chairman of Committees, first, I would like to move the following Resolution under Section 3 of the Active Liability Management Act, No. 8 of 2018:

" That this Parliament resolves that a sum not exceeding Rs. 480 billion may be raised by way of loans, in or outside Sri Lanka for such purposes as specified in terms of the provisions of Section 3 of the Active Liability Management Act, No. 8 of 2018. "

Sir, the Active Liability Management Act, No. 8 of 2018, which we shall call, for short, "ALMA" from hereon, was enacted by Parliament, as you know, on the 23rd of March last year with the objective to improve public debt management in Sri Lanka while ensuring that the financing needs and payment obligations of the Government are met at the lowest possible cost over the medium to long-term consistent with a prudent degree of risk. ALMA enables the Government to raise additional funds or contract liabilities over and above the Parliament approved annual borrowing limit as stipulated in the Appropriation Act subject to the conditions that the funds or liabilities contracted in aggregate should not exceed 10 per cent of the total outstanding debt as at the end of the preceding Financial Year. Further, such funds or liabilities contracted can be used only for the purpose of refinancing and pre-financing of the public debt through liability management. Sir, liability management is a process of restructuring the outstanding debt portfolio of the Government to improve the composition of it and thereby, addressing the possible risk arising from servicing of such debt obligations.

In fact, at this juncture, I would like to note that in 2018, a Resolution was submitted in Parliament under Section 3 of ALMA to raise a sum not exceeding Rs. 360 billion for such purposes as specified in ALMA and that Resolution was approved on the 26th of October last year, the very day the infamous Constitutional coup took place in Sri Lanka when an illegal Government took over the reins of governance for 52 days. However, no funds were raised utilizing that approval, as by that time, the ALMA had not been gazetted as required by Section 1. However, the required Gazette Notification enforcing ALMA, Gazette (Extraordinary) No. 2102/41 dated 21.12.2018, was published immediately after the 52-day Constitutional crisis was resolved and the legal Government was restored.

Sir, the outstanding Central Government debt as at the end of 2018 amounted to Rs. 11,276 billion, which recorded as 78 per cent of GDP. From the total outstanding debt, Rs. 5,531 billion or 49 per cent represents domestic debt while Rs. 5,745 billion, that is 51 per cent, represents foreign currency denominated debt. Today, the debt service payments for the year are estimated at Rs. 2,079. 7 billion, from which 60 per cent is to be incurred for the debt service payments in terms of foreign currency denominated debt.

As at 26th June, 2019, the total actual debt service payments amounted to Rs. 1,131.5 billion including US Dollars 3,929 million debt service in foreign currency terms. The US Dollar requirements for the second half of the year were estimated at US Dollars 2,079 million approximately, and to meet this liability, actions were taken to raise a second ISB for the year 2019 amounting to US Dollars 2,000 million as of 24th June of this year. Within the given borrowing limit under the Appropriation Act, No. 6 of 2019 for the Financial Year 2019, Rs. 767.7 billion has been obtained by way of domestic sources while Rs. 548.6 billion equivalent amount has been obtained by way of foreign sources of financing. This includes International Sovereign Bonds of US Dollars 2,400 million raised in March, 2019 and the foreign financing for development projects amounting to Rs. 77 billion.

In this background, having taken into account the debt maturity structure during the period 2020 - 2029, specially with the continuous maturity of International Sovereign Bonds between 2020 and 2029 of about US Dollars 1,000 to US Dollars 1,500 million per annum, the Monetary Board of the Central Bank of Sri Lanka has recommended to raise an amount not exceeding Rs. 480 billion being 4.26 per cent of the actual outstanding debt, which is Rs. 11,276 billion as at the end 2018, as stated in the Annual Report - 2018 of the Ministry of Finance, which has already been tabled here, by way of loans in or outside Sri Lanka for such purposes as specified in the provisions of ALMA. It must be noted that the yields in the domestic markets in recent times had been showing a downward trend and could remain so in the near term as per analysts. Although the Federal Reserve has not cut rates as expected in its FOMC Meeting in June, 2019, rates have showed a downward trend; in fact, rates have reduced in comparison to 12 months ago. In this context, given the impact of bunching, specially in the ISB spectrum, it is prudent and lenders also feel comfortable if the Government of Sri Lanka is able to access the market when rates are favourable and thereby, engage in active liability management activities which includes pre-payments and rollovers.

In fact, the recent ISB issuance of US Dollars 2,000 million at a maturity of both five and 10 years at 6.35 per cent and 7.55 per cent respectively, which was well subscribed, and also with interest rates of almost 50 to 30 basic points less than the issuance in March, 2019 has indicated that the Government of Sri Lanka is able to access funds in the international markets and that it is also able to do so at a reasonable cost despite the many challenges it has faced since the Easter Sunday attacks. In
fact, that again demonstrates the confidence the international community has in Sri Lanka.

It is in this background, Sir, that the limits for ALMA need to be approved by Parliament so as to enable a more prudent management of public finances. Accordingly, the following Resolution has been submitted to Parliament requesting its approval by me as the Minister of Finance today: Resolution under the Active Liability Management Act, - That this Parliament resolves that a sum not exceeding Rs. 480 billion may be raised by way of loans, in or outside Sri Lanka for such purposes as specified in terms of the provisions of the Section 3 of the Active Liability Management Act, No. 8 of 2018.

In addition to this, Sir, I will also take a few more minutes to present four Orders made in line with the Budget, 2019 and published in Gazette Notifications to the House. Following Excise Duty revisions were made by issuing following Orders under the Excise (Special Provisions) Act, No. 13 of 1989 and published in the Gazette respectively. In fact, Gazette Extraordinary No. 2113/9 dated 05th March, 2019 was issued as a revenue Proposal in the Budget, 2019. The Excise Duty on passenger motor vehicles with an engine capcacity of less than 2,000 cc, three-wheelers and motorcycles was increased by 15 per cent respectively. Along with some other aspects, especially the Excise Duty on cigarettes which are more than 60 millimetres in length was increased by 12 per cent based on the principle of indexation together with a minimum annual revenue increase capturing annual inflation and GDP growth. The Gazette Extraordinary No. 2114/25 dated 13th March, 2019, the Gazette Extraordinary No. 2114/49 dated 14th March, 2019 and the Gazette Extraordinary No. 2123/5 dated 13th May, 2019 relate to the other Orders.

I will not take too much of your time to go into details of each of these Gazette Notifications. But, I would also like to clarify one issue which has been given wide publicity in the newspapers recently.

, . . Question put, and agreed to. : : ACTIVE LIABILITY MANAGEMENT ACT : RESOLUTION
( ) (The Hon. Lakshman Kiriella) Sir, on behalf of the Minister of Finance, I move,

That this Parliament resolves that a sum not exceeding Rs. 480.0 billion may be raised by way of loans, in or outside Sri Lanka for such purposes as specified in terms of the provisions of the Section 3 of the Active Liability Management Act, No. 8 of 2018.
